block.p: Medical Science Honors

TUESDAY -- The Irvington Institute for Immunological Research, which provides fellowships to scientists engaged in disease research, will raise money at a black-tie dinner at the Pierre. Awards will be given to Mrs. John J. Veronis, Dr. Irving Weissman and Jonathan Rothberg. Cocktails at 7 will be followed by dinner at 8 and an awards ceremony. Tickets, $1,000, from (212)576-1005.
Medical Science Honors

TUESDAY -- The Irvington Institute for Immunological Research, which provides fellowships to scientists engaged in disease research, will raise money at a black-tie dinner at the Pierre. Awards will be given to Mrs. John J. Veronis, Dr. Irving Weissman and Jonathan Rothberg. Cocktails at 7 will be followed by dinner at 8 and an awards ceremony. Tickets, $1,000, from (212)576-1005.
Aiding Those With Breast Cancer

WEDNESDAY -- An auction of wine, food and art at Sotheby's will raise money for research, education and support services for women with breast cancer at the Columbia-Presbyterian campus of New York-Presbyterian Hospital. The evening begins with a wine tasting at 6, with a live auction at 7:30. Tickets, $250, from (212)305-2142.
Archival Support

WEDNESDAY -- The Smithsonian Institution's Archives of American Art will raise money for exhibitions, public education efforts and other programs. The black-tie evening begins with cocktails and an exhibition of letters, diaries and other items from the archives, at 6:30 at the archives' New York regional center, housed on the lobby level of the PaineWebber building, 1285 Avenue of the Americas (52nd Street). At 7:30, a cocktail reception begins at the University Club, with dinner at 8:15. Transportation will be provided between the exhibition and the dinner. Mrs. Edsel B. Ford will be among those honored. Tickets, $500, from (212) 399-5030.
Northern Lights

WEDNESDAY -- Karita Mattila, the Finnish soprano, will perform at a dinner and dance at the Grand Hyatt to celebrate the opening, on Nov. 3rd, of Scandinavia House, a cultural center. The evening will raise money for the programs of the American-Scandinavian Foundation. Cocktails at 7 will be followed by dinner at 8. Black tie or national dress. Tickets, $600, from (212) 725-7141.
Doctors on the Move

WEDNESDAY -- Doctors of the World, which provides medical and public health assistance to people in need, will raise money at a dinner at Pier 60, Chelsea Piers. Michael Crichton, the author, and Cynthia Nixon, the actress, will be the hosts of the event. A cocktail reception begins at 6:30, followed by dinner and a silent auction of artwork at 7. Tickets, $1,000, or $500 for the dinner alone, from (212)243-7300.
For Smallest Victims of AIDS

THURSDAY -- An auction of work by African-American, Afro-Caribbean and African artists, at the parish hall of St. Marks-in-the-Bowery Church, 131 East 10th Street, will raise money for meals, health-education and other support programs for African AIDS orphans. The event, benefiting African Action on AIDS, begins at 6 with cocktails, hors d'oeuvres and a silent auction. The live auction begins at 8. Tickets, $30, from (212) 473-6904.
Masquerade for the Arts

THURSDAY -- The National Arts Club, which supports the arts and is located at 15 Gramercy Park South, will hold a Venetian masquerade ball to raise money for its facade restoration project. The evening will include an auction of masks and the presentation of ''The Serpent Woman,'' an 18th-century Venetian comedy, as well as Venetian wine, food and music. Black tie. Cocktails and a buffet dinner will begin at 7:00. Tickets, $150, from (212) 475-3424, ext. 16.
Art and Antiques Show Preview

THURSDAY -- The research and patient care programs of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center will benefit from a preview of the International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Drinks at 6 p.m. Black tie. Tickets, $2,500 for entry at 5:45; $1,000 for admission at 6 ; $500 at 6:30; and $200 at 7. Tickets from (212) 874-5457.
Human Rights Dinner

THURSDAY -- Tom Brokaw will be the master of ceremonies at an awards dinner to raise money for the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights at Pier 60 of the Chelsea Piers Sports Complex. The public interest advocacy organization will honor Han Dongfang, a Chinese labor advocate and journalist, and others. Drinks at 6 will be followed by dinner at 7:30. Tickets, $500, from (877)565-1804.
Health Care for the Homeless

THURSDAY -- A reading at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington, at 54th Street, will aid Care for the Homeless, which coordinates health care. The evening begins with a cocktail reception at 6, followed by a reading by Lee Stringer, the author of ''Grand Central Winter: Stories From the Street'' (Seven Stories Press, 1998). Tickets, $50, from (212) 366-4459.
Purple Haze

OCT. 20 -- Dinner and a performance of ''A Magic Science,'' a musical tribute to Jim Hendrix at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, will raise money for public education and performance programs of the academy. Dinner at 6 , with the concert at 8. A reception with the artists will follow the show at 10. Tickets, $600, or $300 for the concert and reception alone, from (718) 636-4182.
Celebrating Town Hall

OCT. 22 -- A cabaret concert with K. T. Sullivan, Steve Ross, Andrea Marcovicci and others will raise money for Town Hall productions. Jacques D'Amboise and Muriel Siebert will be honored for their contributions to the arts. The concert begins at 3 p.m., with a cocktail reception at the Harvard Club at 5:45. Dinner at 6:30. Tickets, $250, , from (212) 997-1003.
Natalie Cole for Unicef

OCT. 23 -- Natalie Cole will perform at a dinner, at the Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street, to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Trick or Treat for Unicef campaign, which raises money for medicine, clean water, nutrition, education and emergency relief for children in more than 160 countries. Sarah Jessica Parker will be M.C. of the evening, and Ted Turner will be honored. Cocktails at 6, with dinner at 6:30. Tickets, $500, from (212) 997-0100.
Friends for Life

OCT. 23 --Twenty-seven New York chefs will prepare tastings of some of their signature dishes at Chelsea Market at a party to raise money for Children's Friends for Life. The organization provides a variety of services to children infected with H.I.V.-AIDS, including clothing, transportation, dental care and birthday and holiday celebrations. The event begins at 6 (guests enter Chelsea Market on 10th Avenue between 15th and 16th Streets) with a cocktail party with Libby Pataki, Donna Hanover, Susan Lucci and Lara Dutta, the current Miss Universe. Tickets, $300, from (212) 757-0497.
For Leukemia Research

OCT. 23 -- Skitch Henderson and the New York Pops, Judy Collins, Brian Stokes Mitchell, Regis Philbin, Joy Behar and others will perform at a benefit at Carnegie Hall for the research supported by the Lauri Strauss Leukemia Foundation. The concert begins at 7:30, with a cocktail reception to follow. Tickets, $350, or $75 to $100 for the concert alone, from (212) 696-1033.
Grace Foundation Dinner

OCT. 23 -- Aretha Franklin will perform at a dinner and dance at the Waldorf-Astoria to raise money for the scholarships, apprenticeships and fellowships awarded to aspiring actors, playwrights, dancers and filmmakers by the Princess Grace Foundation. The black-tie evening begins with cocktails at 7, with dinner and the awards at 8. Tickets, $600, from (212) 317-1470.
Frick Collection Dinner

OCT. 23 -- An exhibition of 18th- and 19th-century artists, including Edgar Degas and Jean Baptiste Camille Corot, will be on display at the Frick Collection. Proceeds of the event will help promote the study and appreciation of fine and decorative arts at the museum. Rosamond Bernier, the art historian, and John Russell, former chief art critic of The New York Times, will be honored for advancing public interest in the arts. The black-tie evening begins at 7 with drinks; dinner at 8:15. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 327-3165.
Elton John at the Garden

OCT. 23 -- Elton John, Natalie Cole and others will perform at a benefit concert, at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, to raise money for Elton John's AIDS Foundation and for the American Cancer Society's research, education and community health efforts on breast cancer. The event begins at 8. Tickets, $65 and up, from (212) 465-6741.
Championing Health Care

OCT. 24 -- Muhammad Ali will be among those honored at a dinner at the Marriott Marquis to raise money for the Greater New York Chapter of the Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Association. The organization supports clinical services for sufferers of A.L.S., more commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease, at the Beth Israel Medical Center in New York and at the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J.. Drinks and a silent auction of sports memorabilia at 6:30, with dinner at 7:30. Tickets, $750, from (212)619-1400.
Classic Start to a New Season

OCT. 24 -- The fall season of American Ballet Theater will open with selections from Tchaikovsky at a gala at City Center that will raise money for the dance organization's public education and performance programs. The evening begins with a cocktail reception at 5:30, with the performances at 7. A dinner-dance at Essex House, 160 Central Park South, will follow at 9. Tickets, $1,000, or $200 for the reception and the performance alone, from (212) 477-3030, ext. 3239.
A Service Social

OCT. 24 -- The programs of University Settlement, a social services agency on the Lower East Side, will benefit from a dinner at the New York Hilton. The organization is celebrating its new affiliation with Door, a youth services agency, and will honor Jay Walker, the founder of priceline.com. A cocktail reception at 6:30 will be followed by dinner at 7:30. Tickets, $250, from (212) 674-9120, ext. 4558.
